Mae'r amlwg wedi cael eu cymryd fel gweithrefydd a'r Ffynans Act.
Mae'r Ffynans Act wedi'i gweithredu gan y gweithrefydd a'i leda'r byd yma o David Lloyd George.
Roedd yn gweithrefydd o'r cyngor ymlaen.
Roedd y tâcs ymlaen yn y ddod, ac er bod hynny nid wedi cael eu cymryd, roedd yn cael ei ddod yn ystod y ffynans.
I ddod o'r ddod ymlaen o'r Argymru i ddod i'w gweithrefydd cymorth, Arrel yn cael ei motobaith Triumph.

Now, where does he go to work on the assessment of every farm in Parish Llandygwyth?
The parish of Llandygwyth is the very south of the county, it's near Newcastle Emily,
but the parish is borders between Pembrokeshire, Cardiganshire and Carmarthenshire.
Arrel took lodgings at the village of Cwmcoi and that's in the Tyvee valley between Newcastle Emily and Cynarth.

What farms he visited.

Let me look at the map of the farm.

So there's meadows along the Tyvee that would land in the middle and the extent of the farm otherwise.
The survey map has a certain number.
It's 106, 107 and there's some details of the parish maps.
On the census of 1911, I wanted to know who lived at Penmenach Farm at that time.
The census of 1911 gives me Mary Ann Edwards, head of the farm and she's a widow.
She's the daughter Harriet Edwards who is singling.
So between those two censuses, David Edwards had passed away and Mary Ann Edwards became head of the farm and a steward.
Harriet leaves Penmenach with her mother for her marriage to Arell.
The marriage took place on 29 August 1914.
At this August, the first World War is at its height and the Germans advance on the Western Front.
Britain has declared war on Germany and the invasion of the neutral Belgium.
Arell marries Harriet who is 26 years old at Cwmquod Chapel and his brother is a witness and a cousin as I know.
The marriage certificate tells me that Arell described themselves as a land valuer.
They were married by the Minister David Evans.
Mary Ann, the mother-in-law of Arell, is still in the picture in 1916.
She transfers her tenancy of Penmenach Farm jointly to Harriet, her daughter, and Arell, her son-in-law.
We have a document that shows the price of this document.
The document in 1915 costs £22.06.
The landlord is Lloyd Williams of Glanaravon.

That's where the Lloyd Williams family is.
He's the lieutenant Lloyd Williams.
Arell and Harriet set about the farm.
It's mainly Arell that does the work.
He looks at every field on the farm and calculates what rent he will pay to his landlord.
I have a collection of the field names and records of them.
The rent for 222 acres is £222.
It's always paid in half yearly sums.
We know that if a tyvee runs through the land, the water for field troughs and the farm yard buildings from a tyvee is coming into place in 1931.
The lister is the maker of the pumps used.
The lister representative called Read the Water Pump on Wednesday.
It hits the water pipe as far as the farm yard and sheds, running water in caution water taps and made concrete water troughs.
Now we've seen how he measures up the value of his land.
Now he starts to feed every field.
So as a tenant he arranges that each field has tens and tens of slag.
Now it wasn't enough to give slag to everybody.
He wants to measure what percentage of slag and what price is the slag.
The slag is bought at the corp in Ywcas Lemlin.
Basic slag is a by-product from the steel furnaces and rich in lime and used as fertilisers.
Slag sweetens the grass to feed the soil and reduce acidity.
It's good for grazing.
The slag was at 42% or 24% and these varied in price of course.
The corp in Ywcas Lemlin, again it's just above the bridge in Ywcas Lemlin, the river Tyvee.
It was in place.
So what did the farm buy at the corp?
So let's look at the sales of butter at the time in 1917.
The sale of butter is at one shilling's eight pence a pound.
The price of one egg is 10 pence.
But in December the price of eggs went up to three and a half pence.
The seed potatoes of the land was three pounds.
Now in this sales account I come across that the motorcycle triumph that he started his career with the South of the county was sold for 30 pounds.

And eight tons of slag is 19 pounds eight shilling's.

And the labour costs are also included in this book.

So they're a range of farm building stock.

Ar yr aros iawn, yn y pen bennan, yna byddai'n cael y cyfrifion ychydig.
